metadata.name: (kinder)Garden, Monuments #168
metadata.description:
When Yazid and Zancan started their fxcollab journey, they knew very little about each other. They learnt about their rich cultural differences, their complementary graphic styles, and a 7-hour timezone difference. What they did have in common was each had two kids about the same age (one a pair of girls, the other boys).

Every kid was born a builder; every kid likes to sit in nature. It’s their way of discovering the world and dreaming of their future accomplishments. While they marvel at the heights of the cities and monuments they construct out of stacks of cubes, parents marvel at their ability to elaborate an unlimited range of worlds out of a limited range of materials. 

This project celebrates the humble and versatile cube. A deceptively simple yet powerful object of play and learning, regardless of age, whether you’re stacking them up in a sandbox, or learning 3D graphics for the first time. 

This project is dedicated to kids, those who were once children, to the dreamers and builders who still enjoy playing with cubes.

Coded in Vanilla JS, the project combines Yazid's iconic “Hashed/Hatched” aesthetic incorporated into childhood wooden toy block structures, and Zancan's signature lush foliage and framework, which enables all iterations to be plottable.
 
Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to get a SVG file suited for plotters
- Click on the image to download a 4K resolution PNG

metadata.name: Annum #8042
metadata.description:
This project is being released in celebration of the 1 year aniversary of Achromat, my first release on fxhash. In addition to being inspired by Achromat, aspects of other previous projects have been incorporated. My deepest gratitude to all who have collected my work over the past year.

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

50% of primary sales go to Savepakistan.

metadata.name: CHROMATLAS, Vol. 6 #103
metadata.description:
[...so I asked myself why it was that we often find images from science beautiful.]

There is a keyboard key that unlocks more variations.

metadata.name: Over the Air #249
metadata.description:
During the last couple of decades, over the air television signals and antennas switched to digital, bringing with them a new form of static and distortion as the signal is broken up. "Over the Air" is inspired by these digital distortions, incorporating aspects of them into the same grid-like structure seen on the television. Additional patterns are combined in the grid with these distortions to create the final artwork.

Patterns for the individual blocks in the grid are divided into categories, and various amounts are picked for each work, with dozens of possible mixtures. Patterns can flow in different directions across the varied canvases. Distribution of these patterns across the grid varies from work to work, providing for different feels as they bunch together or spread apart.

metadata.name: l∞p #63
metadata.description: l∞p

metadata.name: Geode #44
metadata.description:
A single seed shape is chosen from 13, and placed onto the plane. At every step, a copy of this seed is laid edge-to-edge adjacent to an existing shape, without causing any overlaps. This copy is colored based on the edge it shares with the existing shape. The process continues until the animation completes.

New shapes are placed closest to a moving target. In some mints, this target is slow moving, causing new shapes to expand radially from the seed. In other mints, this target races around, causing new shapes to chase it. 

Each of the 13 shapes forms different patterns under different circumstances. Not all patterns will be explored.

Controls:
  - SPACE: Pause/unpause the animation.
  - ENTER: Skip the animation.
  - R: Restart the animation.

URL Params:
  - "preview=1": Skip the animation.
  - "flex=1": Adapt the boundaries to the size of the window.
  - “slow=1”: Draw only one shape per frame.

Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Almost #49
metadata.description:
Hello, I am a 13-year-old girl who has put together this image-composition project for my project-based-learning end-of-term project.  This term we learned about biodiversity and how biodiversity loss affects us and the world around us.  All the images in this project are hand-drawn (on an iPad) by me.

I will be donating all proceeds from the minting of this project to plant trees.  Secondary royalties will be kept by me.  Thank you all ahead of time for your support!

metadata.name: tratti #55
metadata.description:
"tratti" is an Italian word that has many different meanings. When we started working on this piece, we wanted to create something that combines our traits ("tratti" in Italian).
We had this urge to channel the turbulent times we're living in now into this artwork using just lines ("tratti" in Italian).

We don't know what to do now, we're here, and that's all that matters. We're here for our families, our friends, and our community. Like everything in life, there are joyful times and challenging times. We must accept happiness as something that is not constant but that we feel at times (a "tratti" in Italian).

With "tratti", we want to send a message to every disheartened human being: "Stay strong and never let anyone or anything crush the hope in you. Joyful times are around the corner".

---- 

© 2022 — Alessandro Fiore x Emanuele Pasin
LICENSE.md for detailed licensing info

metadata.name: Garden, Monoliths #106
metadata.description:
"Garden, Monoliths" is the result of an algorithm that started in April 2021. It was called "Grass.js".
Spring was blooming all around the house, taking over the stones and remnants of ancient battles that stood here. Inspiration was everywhere.
The initial goal was to use mathematical formulas for creating patterns inspired by the density of nature, that could be used by a pen plotter, so it kept focusing on outputting vector lines. This history and practice produced a graphical style based on line strokes, plus occasionally some transparent, filled shapes.
Each artwork will be either "Garden" or "Monolith", for they are variations of two existing designs from the workshop.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #196
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. “The Bugged Tree”’s code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren’t under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there’s a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: Klyft #785
metadata.description:
“Klyft” is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft’s expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

· URL parameters ·

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> — See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> — See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> — View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true — Save the piece as an image. 

record=true — Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‘Stokkendahl Dalgas’ color scheme:

color=14&record=true

· Interactions ·

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

· Accessibility ·

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS’ VoiceOver, and uses p5.js’ describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don’t hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

· Credits and license ·

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).

metadata.name: GPT-3 and me (free companion mint) #82
metadata.description: Free companion piece to my first Fx(text) article! I have never coded a single line of Javascript in my entire life, yet GPT-3 was able to write the code for this work via my inputs. To read the full article visit: https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/gpt-3-and-me:-a-generative-coding-study

metadata.name: Action; System #8
metadata.description:
Action; system is an experimental study inspired by the work of François Morellet. Morellet was one of the founders of the Groupe de Recherche d'Art Visuel (GRAV), founded in the 60s. His work was often informed by systems, a set of rules that determine the artwork, reducing the artist's subjectivity to a minimum.

This work explores what happens when we let go of the strict rule set. Do we ever fully let go?

-----------------
This work was released for the 2023 fundraising exhibition Cure3, and all of the proceeds and 1% of royalties will go to Parkinson's research funds. You can find more information at https://cure3.co.uk/.

-----------------
Controls
- R: new randomized output (the chances of recovering one of these outputs are very slim, that's what the next control is for)
- E: high-res output
- Double click: fullscreen

While you see the eye of Horus, your artwork is loading.

------------------
Made with p5.js & glsl
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: thébaïde #8
metadata.description:
“Thébaïde” is a french word for wild place, remote and peaceful, where to live in a calm retreat. It's also simply a desert and a synonym of solitude. It comes from Thebaid, an arid region of ancient Egypt and Thebes was the capital.

“thébaïde” is my debut on fx(hash), almost one year since my first works minted on Objkt (a series of Indian ink drawings, in January 2022). After learning the basics of creative coding recently, and a few works with this technique, I decided to create a first generative project. With "thébaïde" I chose to express the minimalist and narrative aspects of my artistic approach (though the title and concept emerged at the end). Gradually the work was resonating with philosophical matters I'm obsessed with since years: time, emptiness, human condition, erosion, desire, chance, combining them into a visual metaphor. The view of a vast area, a changing silhouette, an impenetrable monolith or an opening to elsewhere or nothing, day and night and day and night and dawn and dusk — few elements able to compose a meditative and lasting tableau of questions and feelings.

Press “s” in live mode to save the work.
Made with p5js | 2023
Png | 2000 px x 2000 px | 72 ppi

www.antoniowerli.com

metadata.name: CHX-1 #189
metadata.description:
Glitching pixels like it’s 1999.

Inspired by 90’s digital aesthetics, CHX-1 takes a random selection of GAN seeds, combines them in unique ways, and processes them –individually and as a group– with a series of glitching dithering algorithms. Generating fun, original, colorful artworks. Millions of possibilities. Have fun!

<<< Base seeds generated offline using personal styleGAN2-ADA models. Image processing and combinations done generatively by the CHX-1 algorithm >>>

GAN –> p5js –> Blockchain


• Artworks can take a few seconds to load when running live code.

• Press “s” (when "open live" is active) to save a PNG image.


Copyright (©) 2022 Thomas Noya
Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

◉_◉

metadata.name: Mi  #6
metadata.description:
"Mi" for Mimicry
By imitating the colours and shapes of nature, the project seeks to create a digital version of reality that is both familiar and surreal. The resulting landscapes are at once recognizable and otherworldly, inviting viewers to explore the boundaries between the natural and the artificial.

"Mi" as a musical note
"Mi" synthesises a noise function to create dramatic landscapes, much like a musician who manipulates the frequencies of a musical composition.

"Mi" for Mile/Minute
Creating art is a journey that can take us down unexpected paths, and "Mi" embraces the idea of exploration and experimentation.

Tech Note
Please use the quality settings (press "Q") to generate a higher quality image. The project has been optimised for maximum performance, so it can be rendered on older machines. You can also adjust the resolution to your liking by pressing "R".

Press "S" to save the image.

The code has been tested on my old MacBook and various Windows machines. For best results, please use a modern Chromium-based browser, and ensure that your browser supports WebGL 2.


superbialux

metadata.name: (recombination/perspectives)-I: Horizons #76
metadata.description:
🌊 🌞 🌈 🌅


    ( r e c o m b i n a t i o n  /  p e r s p e c t i v e s ) 


                     I :   H o r i z o n s


                            ✨ 🧬 🧡 ⏲







-----
* What/How *

2 560 000 particles are subjected to a succession of 64 energy bursts which scatters the points through space. 
The algorithm then stores 3 configurations of points, forming an entangled coherent system.
After few seconds multiple observation modalities are then selected sequentially to allow for dynamic and contemplative visualization.

-----
* Mint preview *

Minter will get a 2160x2160 PNG bitmap and an infinite randomly deterministic animation.

-----
* Technics *

This experience is designed to be executed on a recent GPU (>2016) and displayed on 16/9 screens from FHD to 8K+ (1920x1080 → 7680x4320) at 60FPS for infinite duration.

- JavaScript / ThreeJS / WebGL / GLSL
- Unique generative, random and determinist animation (animation is seeded by the fxhash mint hash)
- Infinite animation
- Animation sequences duration between 6 and 60 seconds.

-----
* Controls *

Keyboard "Space" : take a PNG capture of the current view frame (same ratio as window, max 1920x1080)

Keyboard "X" : skip current animation sequence / next sequence

-----
* URL modifiers *

"&fastdemo=on"
Forces animation sequences to last 10 seconds instead of random durations.

"&slow=on"
Forces animation sequences to last 1 minute instead of random durations.

"&static=on"
Disables animation automatic start. Press "X" to start animations.


-----
@HAL09999 – January 25th, 2023

metadata.name: Lands #70
metadata.description:
Lands are a group of artworks creating a minimalist and abstract satellite view. The earth is changing, more and more, day after day, the satellite views are a great proof of that. Stay aware and be careful is important.

I wanted to representing something real, linked with my values, and keep a beautiful composition and colors harmony.  I worked with a new fresh touch for the colors management.

The size, position and frequency of the pieces are generated for each token, along with the color theme. 

Features : 
- piecesCount : the number of circles and rectangles.
- glitchLinesCount :  the number of lines behind the shapes.
- MultipleGlitchDirections : if the directions of the lines behind are just horizontal or vertical, or both (10% of chance to have only one direction) .

 Handmade by code with Javascript, made with fragment.tools
 Quentin Hocdé, Brussels (Belgium), 2023.
